1090410.1007/10904.1574-1451Journal of Inorganic and Organometallic Polymers and MaterialsJ Inorg Organomet Polym1574-14431574-1451Springer USNew Yorks10904-015-0216-321610.1007/s10904-015-0216-3ArticleIonothermal Synthesis of a 3D Luminescent Strontium(II) Coordination Polymer with Dodecanuclear Metallocyclic Ring SegmentsLiuShun-Shun1ChengMeng1LiBing1ShiWen-Hui1BaiYan1eDangDong-Bin1fgrid.256922.8000000009139560XKey Laboratory of Polyoxometalate Chemistry of Henan Province, Institute of Molecular and Crystal Engineering, School of Chemistry and Chemical EngineeringHenan University475004KaifengPeople’s Republic of Chinabaiyan@henu.edu.cndangdb@henu.edu.cn253201592015255110311101932015202201519320152532015© Springer Science+Business Media New York 20152015Abstract

A new Sr(II) coordination polymer (EMIm)4[Sr10(1,4-NDC)10Br4] 1 has been ionothermal synthesized using 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide as solvent and characterized by IR, elemental analysis, XRPD and X-ray crystallography, where 1,4-H2NDC is 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid. Polymer 1 displays a crystalline 3D framework, in which the anions of 1,4-H2NDC are embedded in three bridging coordination modes and Sr(II) centers show five coordination geometries. Each dodecanuclear metallocyclic ring segment formed by distorted edge-sharing and face-sharing Sr coordination polyhedra extends out to increase the dimensionality by strontium coordination polyhedra sharing to obtain a rare Sr-based 2D sheet. Organic bridging ligands connect adjacent layers giving rise to a 3D structure and (EMIm)+ cations acting as extra charge balancing species occupy the channels of the anionic framework. The luminescent properties of polymer 1 at room temperature were investigated.

Much interest at present is focused on the rational design and construction of coordination polymers (CPs) owing to their intriguing aesthetic structures and special functional properties such as optics, redox activity and magnetism [1–4]. Many reaction factors, such as the types of organic ligands, metal–ligand ratio, solvent systems, counter ions, temperature and even the reaction time, are found to influence the kinetics and energetics of the growth of CPs. Among them, the introduction of green solvent systems is undoubtedly a design highlight in assembling CPs [5, 6]. In the past two decades, ionic liquids (ILs) have been widely used as “green solvents” replacing traditional organic solvents for organic synthesis and catalysis. Moreover, ionothermal synthesis as a promising method to prepare CPs has received remarkable attention in which ILs function as reaction media, structure templates or charge-compensating groups [7–9]. In comparison with aqueous solutions and/or typical organic solvents, ILs as organic salts composed completely of ions have many outstanding physicochemical properties, such as nonflammability, negligible vapor pressure, high ionic conductivity, excellent dissolving capacity, and thermostablility [10–12].

In many cases, ionothermal reactions often yield new materials, which cannot or not easily be made via conventional approaches. However, there are still limited known examples of coordination frameworks synthesized in ILs [7, 13–15], and most of these structures with metal cations being transitions and rare-earth but few in alkaline earth metals [16]. In the construction of CPs, alkaline earth-organic frameworks are still a subject of current interest because of the large atomic radii and broad span of coordination number of alkaline earth atoms making the topologies of polymers uncontrollable and diverting [17, 18]. To date, to the best of our knowledge, Sr-based CP has not been reported under ionothermal conditions. In the present study, as the luminescence behavior of product was desired, we opted to use 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid as functional component to synthesize an interesting 3D CP (EMIm)4[Sr10(1,4-NDC)10Br4] 1 using 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide as solvent. In 1 both the cations and anions of the ILs enter the resulting framework which displays strong fluorescent emission in the solid state at room temperature.

ExperimentalMaterials and Measurements

All chemicals were of reagent grade quality obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. 1-Ethyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide ([EMIM]Br) IL was prepared according to the literature method [19]. Elemental analyses (C, H and N) were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analytical instrument. IR spectra were recorded in KBr pellets with a Nicolet 170 SXFT-IR spectrophotometer in the 4000–400 cm−1 region. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns were recorded on a D/max-γ A rotating anode X-ray diffractometer with Cu sealed tube (λ = 1.54178 Å), and the luminescent spectra were performed on a Hitachi F-7000 fluorescence spectrophotometer.

Synthesis of (EMIm)<sub>4</sub>[Sr<sub>10</sub>(1,4-NDC)<sub>10</sub>Br<sub>4</sub>] (<bold>1</bold>)

Polymer 1 was synthesized by ionothermal method. A mixture of 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (1,4-H2NDC) (0.241 g, 1.0 mmol), Sr(NO3)2·2H2O (0.211 g, 1.0 mmol), NaOH (0.086 g, 2.0 mmol) and [EMIM]Br (0.996 g) was sealed in a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel bomb and heated at 180 °C for 72 h. Then the autoclave was cooled to room temperature and the yellow crystals were isolated and washed with ethanol. Yield: ca. 62 % (based on 1,4-H2NDC). Calcd (%) for C144H104Br4N8O40Sr10: C, 45.73; H, 2.77; N, 2.96. Found: C, 45.62; H, 2.83; N, 3.02. IR (cm−1, KBr pellet): 3409(m), 1556(vs), 1512(w), 1461(m), 1418(s), 1369(vs), 1262(m), 1211(w), 1164(m), 1051(w), 881(w), 841(m), 789(m), 619(w), 574(w), 433(w), 376(w).

X-ray Crystallography

A suitable sample of size 0.20 mm × 0.15 mm × 0.13 mm was chosen for the crystallographic study and then mounted on a Bruker Smart APEX II CCD diffractometer with ω and φ scan mode in the range of 2.44° < θ < 20.92°. All diffraction measurements were performed at room temperature using graphite monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). A total of 36255 (12204 independent, Rint = 0.1084) reflections were measured. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined on F2 by using full-matrix least-squares methods with SHELXTL version 5.1 [20]. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by full-matrix least-squares techniques and all hydrogen atoms were geometrically fixed to allow riding on the parent atoms to which they are attached. Structure solution and refinement based on 7665 independent reflections with I > 2σ(I). Space group, lattice parameters and other relevant information are listed in Table 1 and selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table 2.

Results and DiscussionIR Spectrum

In the IR spectrum of polymer 1, the strong broaden absorption band at 1556 cm−1 shows the characteristic stretching frequency of ν(–CO2, asym), and the bands at 1418 and 1369 cm−1 are assigned as the ν(–CO2, sym) stretching frequency [21, 22]. This result indicates that the carboxyl groups of 1,4-H2NDC have joined in different coordination modes, which agrees well with the date of the other relevant compounds [16]. Their identities were finally confirmed by X-ray crystallography.

Description of the Structure (EMIm)<sub>4</sub>[Sr<sub>10</sub>(1,4-NDC)<sub>10</sub>Br<sub>4</sub>] (<bold>1</bold>)

The structure analysis by X-ray single crystal diffraction revealed that the structure of 1 exhibits a crystalline 3D framework with exciting dodecanuclear metallocyclic ring (Sr12-ring) segments. The ORTEP diagram of 1 with the atomic numbering scheme and the coordination environment of metal ions is depicted in Fig. 1. The asymmetric unit consists of five Sr(II) atoms, five 1,4-NDC2− ligands, two Br− anions and two (EMIm)+ cations.

Sr1 and Sr2 are located in seven-coordinated capped octahedral coordination geometry with O6Br set from five 1,4-NDC2− ligands and one Br− anion (Fig. 2). For Sr1, O6, O9, O10A, O15A, O20B and Br1 occupy the octahedral position while O5 occupies the capped position. Sr2 bonds to O11, O13, O18, O17, O8C, O14D and Br2, in which O17 occupies the capped position. The Sr1–O and Sr2–O distances are in the ranges of 2.439(12)–2.784(11) and 2.462(11)–2.766(10) Å, respectively. Different from the coordination modes of Sr1 and Sr2, the other three Sr centers (Sr3, Sr4 and Sr5) are eight-coordinate environment. Sr3 and Sr4 are coordinated by seven oxygen atoms and one three-link bromine atom. The seven oxygen donors around Sr3 metal center include two oxygen atoms (O1, O5) of two μ2–η2:η1 groups, four oxygen atoms (O9A, O10A, O15E, O16E) coming from two μ3–η2:η2 groups, another one oxygen atom O19F belonging to μ2–η1:η1 group. While Sr4 is connected with seven oxygen atoms of which O3G and O17 being in two μ2–η2:η1 carboxylate groups, O11, O12, O13D, O14D of two μ3–η2:η2 carboxylate groups and the remaining O7G coming from μ2–η1:η1 carboxylate group. The average strontium-oxygen distance is 2.67 Å for Sr3–O and 2.65 Å for Sr4–O, respectively. It is again of the type that the coordination environment of Sr5 is also eight-coordinated but with six oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O3G, O4G, O12, O16E) of four 1,4-NDC2− and two bromine atoms (Br1 and Br2D) around the metal center. The structure shows that the Sr5 adopts a distorted hexagonal bipyramidal configuration in which Br1 and Br2D occupy the vertex positions with the Br–Sr5–Br angel of 175.2° and the average Sr5–Br distance of 3.06 Å. The Sr5–O distances are in the range of 2.527(10)–2.983(16) Å.

In the asymmetric unit of 1, the anions of 1,4-H2NDC present three interesting bridging ligands, μ6-(μ3–η2:η2)-(μ3–η2:η2) (1,4-NDC2−-1), μ4-(μ2–η2:η1)-(μ2–η2:η1) (1,4-NDC2−-2) and μ4-(μ2–η1:η1)-(μ2–η2:η1) (1,4-NDC2−-3), respectively (Fig. 3). An exciting dodecanuclear metallocyclic ring (Sr12-ring) segment is formed by distorted edge-sharing and face-sharing Sr coordination polyhedra, in which the trapped inside the void two 1,4-NDC2−-1 bridging ligands may have a great influence on structure (Fig. 4). As such, obvious face-to-face π–π interaction between two aromatic rings is found and characterized by the centroid–centroid separation of 3.70 Å, the shortest interplanar atom–atom separation of 3.57 Å, and the dihedral angel of 4.6°, respectively. Each Sr12-ring extends out to increase the dimensionality by strontium coordination polyhedra sharing to obtain a rare Sr-based 2D sheet. 1,4-NDC2−-2 and 1,4-NDC2−-3 connect adjacent layers giving rise to a 3D structure and (EMIm)+ cations acting as extra charge balancing species occupy the channels of the anionic framework (Fig. 5). It is interesting to note that there are obvious one type of face-to-face π–π interaction and multiform C–H···π interactions involving naphthalene rings and imidazole rings of ILs. The π–π interaction between two benzene rings of 1,4-NDC2−-2 and 1,4-NDC2−-3 is characterized by the centroid–centroid separation of 3.73 Å, the shortest interplanar atom–atom separation of 3.47 Å, and the dihedral angel of 12.0°, respectively. At the same time, there is one type of C–H···π interaction with the C···π separation of 3.62 Å and the C–H···π angle of 128.0°. Two C–H···π interactions between naphthalene rings and imidazole rings are characterized by the C···π separation of 3.34, 3.54 Å and the C–H···π angle of 136.8°, 106.2°, respectively. In addition, multiple hydrogen bonds, C–H···Br and C–H···O, are found in the network cooperatively stabilizing polymeric structure (Table 3). Apparently, extensive cooperativity throughout the crystals is important for such materials.

X-ray Powder Diffraction

To ensure the phase purity of the samples for the luminescence determination, the XRPD pattern of 1 was performed. As shown in Fig. 6, the peak positions of simulated and experimental patterns are in good agreement with each other, demonstrating the phase purity of the products. The dissimilarities in intensity may be due to the preferred orientation of the crystalline powder samples.

Luminescence Properties

Luminescence in CPs generally arises from conjugated organic ligands and/or metal ions or clusters [1]. Herein, we opted to use 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid as functional component to synthesize luminescence CP, due to they has exhibited behaviors in their rich structural chemistry and prominent luminescent properties [7, 16, 23–25]. On the other hand, although the photoluminescence was greatly enhanced by the coordination of alkaline earth metal ion, the luminescent properties of alkaline earth metal organic–inorganic hybrid materials in the solid states have not been well-studied up to now [16, 26]. Accordingly, the photoluminescent spectra of 1 in the solid state have been measured at the room temperature. Upon the excitation at 271 nm, polymer 1 shows a strong emission peak at 377 nm, as show in Fig. 7. Excitation of solid samples of 1 at 377 nm produces two emission peaks at 271 and 336 nm. The 271 nm excitation was chosen because it is suitable for polymer 1 to exist the strong emission peak. Compared to the luminescent spectrum of the free 1,4-H2NDC ligand at about 475 nm, the emission of 1 may be assigned to oxygen to Sr(II) charge transfer transitions, which is similar to that of {(EMIm)2[Zn7(μ4-O)2(1,4-NDC)6]}n [24]. Noticeably, aromatic components in the framework is expected to better attract each other through abundant π–π interactions and may play a key role in luminescent spectrum of 1.

Conclusions

In summary, we presented a new CP (EMIm)4[Sr10(1,4-NDC)10Br4] (1) based on 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid by a ionothermal reaction in an imidazolium-based IL as solvent. The structure of polymer 1 has been established by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis and also characterized by IR, XRPD analysis and luminescent properties. Polymer 1 displays a crystalline 3D framework with dodecanuclear metallocyclic ring segments, in which both the cations and anions of the ILs enter the resulting framework. Multiform supramolecular interactions are found in the 3D structure and also play an important role in stabilizing the network. The fluorescence measurement of polymer 1 shows the strong emission peak in the solid state. Because ionothermal syntheses are efficient and environmentally benign, we believe that this strategy is very promising in the design and construction of functional CPs. Further such studies are currently underway.

Their identities were finally confirmed by X-ray crystallography.Description of the Structure (EMIm)4[Sr10(1,4-NDC)10Br4] (1)The structure analysis by X-ray single crystal diffraction revealed that the structure of 1 exhibits a crystalline 3D framework with exciting dodecanuclear metallocyclic ring (Sr12-ring) segments. The ORTEP diagram of 1 with the atomic numbering scheme and the coordination environment of metal ions is depicted in Fig. 1. The asymmetric unit consists of five Sr(II) atoms, five 1,4-NDC2- ligands, two Br- anions and two (EMIm)+ cations.Sr1 and Sr2 are located in seven-coordinated capped octahedral coordination geometry with O6Br set from five 1,4-NDC2- ligands and one Br- anion (Fig. 2). For Sr1, O6, O9, O10A, O15A, O20B and Br1 occupy the octahedral position while O5 occupies the capped position. Sr2 bonds to O11, O13, O18, O17, O8C, O14D and Br2, in which O17 occupies the capped position. The Sr1-O and Sr2-O distances are in the ranges of 2.439(12)-2.784(11) and 2.462(11)-2.766(10) Å, respectively. Different from the coordination modes of Sr1 and Sr2, the other three Sr centers (Sr3, Sr4 and Sr5) are eight-coordinate environment. Sr3 and Sr4 are coordinated by seven oxygen atoms and one three-link bromine atom. The seven oxygen donors around Sr3 metal center include two oxygen atoms (O1, O5) of two μ2-η2:η1 groups, four oxygen atoms (O9A, O10A, O15E, O16E) coming from two μ3-η2:η2 groups, another one oxygen atom O19F belonging to μ2-η1:η1 group. While Sr4 is connected with seven oxygen atoms of which O3G and O17 being in two μ2-η2:η1 carboxylate groups, O11, O12, O13D, O14D of two μ3-η2:η2 carboxylate groups and the remaining O7G coming from μ2-η1:η1 carboxylate group. The average strontium-oxygen distance is 2.67 Å for Sr3-O and 2.65 Å for Sr4-O, respectively. It is again of the type that the coordination environment of Sr5 is also eight-coordinated but with six oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O3G, O4G, O12, O16E) of four 1,4-NDC2- and two bromine atoms (Br1 and Br2D) around the metal center. The structure shows that the Sr5 adopts a distorted hexagonal bipyramidal configuration in which Br1 and Br2D occupy the vertex positions with the Br-Sr5-Br angel of 175.2° and the average Sr5-Br distance of 3.06 Å. The Sr5-O distances are in the range of 2.527(10)-2.983(16) Å.In the asymmetric unit of 1, the anions of 1,4-H2NDC present three interesting bridging ligands, μ6-(μ3-η2:η2)-(μ3-η2:η2) (1,4-NDC2--1), μ4-(μ2-η2:η1)-(μ2-η2:η1) (1,4-NDC2--2) and μ4-(μ2-η1:η1)-(μ2-η2:η1) (1,4-NDC2--3), respectively (Fig. 3). An exciting dodecanuclear metallocyclic ring (Sr12-ring) segment is formed by distorted edge-sharing and face-sharing Sr coordination polyhedra, in which the trapped inside the void two 1,4-NDC2--1 bridging ligands may have a great influence on structure (Fig. 4). As such, obvious face-to-face π-π interaction between two aromatic rings is found and characterized by the centroid-centroid separation of 3.70 Å, the shortest interplanar atom-atom separation of 3.57 Å, and the dihedral angel of 4.6°, respectively. Each Sr12-ring extends out to increase the dimensionality by strontium coordination polyhedra sharing to obtain a rare Sr-based 2D sheet. 1,4-NDC2--2 and 1,4-NDC2--3 connect adjacent layers giving rise to a 3D structure and (EMIm)+ cations acting as extra charge balancing species occupy the channels of the anionic framework (Fig. 5). It is interesting to note that there are obvious one type of face-to-face π-π interaction and multiform C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions involving naphthalene rings and imidazole rings of ILs. The π-π interaction between two benzene rings of 1,4-NDC2--2 and 1,4-NDC2--3 is characterized by the centroid-centroid separation of 3.73 Å, the shortest interplanar atom-atom separation of 3.47 Å, and the dihedral angel of 12.0°, respectively. At the same time, there is one type of C-H⋅⋅⋅π interaction with the C⋅⋅⋅π separation of 3.62 Å and the C-H⋅⋅⋅π angle of 128.0°. Two C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions between naphthalene rings and imidazole rings are characterized by the C⋅⋅⋅π separation of 3.34, 3.54 Å and the C-H⋅⋅⋅π angle of 136.8°, 106.2°, respectively. In addition, multiple hydrogen bonds, C-H⋅⋅⋅Br and C-H⋅⋅⋅O, are found in the network cooperatively stabilizing polymeric structure (Table 3). Apparently, extensive cooperativity throughout the crystals is important for such materials.X-ray Powder DiffractionTo ensure the phase purity of the samples for the luminescence determination, the XRPD pattern of 1 was performed. As shown in Fig. 6, the peak positions of simulated and experimental patterns are in good agreement with each other, demonstrating the phase purity of the products. The dissimilarities in intensity may be due to the preferred orientation of the crystalline powder samples.Luminescence PropertiesLuminescence in CPs generally arises from conjugated organic ligands and/or metal ions or clusters [1]. Herein, we opted to use 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid as functional component to synthesize luminescence CP, due to they has exhibited behaviors in their rich structural chemistry and prominent luminescent properties [7, 16, 23-25]. On the other hand, although the photoluminescence was greatly enhanced by the coordination of alkaline earth metal ion, the luminescent properties of alkaline earth metal organic-inorganic hybrid materials in the solid states have not been well-studied up to now [16, 26]. Accordingly, the photoluminescent spectra of 1 in the solid state have been measured at the room temperature. Upon the excitation at 271 nm, polymer 1 shows a strong emission peak at 377 nm, as show in Fig. 7. Excitation of solid samples of 1 at 377 nm produces two emission peaks at 271 and 336 nm. The 271 nm excitation was chosen because it is suitable for polymer 1 to exist the strong emission peak. Compared to the luminescent spectrum of the free 1,4-H2NDC ligand at about 475 nm, the emission of 1 may be assigned to oxygen to Sr(II) charge transfer transitions, which is similar to that of {(EMIm)2[Zn7(μ4-O)2(1,4-NDC)6]}n [24]. Noticeably, aromatic components in the framework is expected to better attract each other through abundant π-π interactions and may play a key role in luminescent spectrum of 1.ConclusionsIn summary, we presented a new CP (EMIm)4[Sr10(1,4-NDC)10Br4] (1) based on 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid by a ionothermal reaction in an imidazolium-based IL as solvent. The structure of polymer 1 has been established by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis and also characterized by IR, XRPD analysis and luminescent properties. Polymer 1 displays a crystalline 3D framework with dodecanuclear metallocyclic ring segments, in which both the cations and anions of the ILs enter the resulting framework. Multiform supramolecular interactions are found in the 3D structure and also play an important role in stabilizing the network. The fluorescence measurement of polymer 1 shows the strong emission peak in the solid state. Because ionothermal syntheses are efficient and environmentally benign, we believe that this strategy is very promising in the design and construction of functional CPs. Further such studies are currently underway.Supplementary MaterialCrystallographic information of polymer (EMIm)4[Sr10(1,4-NDC)10Br4] has been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre as supplementary publication number CCDC 1033958 a Copy of the data may be obtained free of charge on application to CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK (fax: +44-1223-336-033; e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk or www:http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk).AcknowledgmentsThis work was supported by the Foundation of the Education Department of Henan Province of China (13A150045) and the Foundation of Students Innovative Experiment Program of Henan University (14NB035).References1.HuZCDeilbertBJLiJChem. elements.content: A new Sr(II) coordination polymer (EMIm)4[Sr10(1,4-NDC)10Br4] 1 has been ionothermal synthesized using 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide as solvent and characterized by IR, elemental analysis, XRPD and X-ray crystallography, where 1,4-H2NDC is 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid. Polymer 1 displays a crystalline 3D framework, in which the anions of 1,4-H2NDC are embedded in three bridging coordination modes and Sr(II) centers show five coordination geometries. Each dodecanuclear metallocyclic ring segment formed by distorted edge-sharing and face-sharing Sr coordination polyhedra extends out to increase the dimensionality by strontium coordination polyhedra sharing to obtain a rare Sr-based 2D sheet. Organic bridging ligands connect adjacent layers giving rise to a 3D structure and (EMIm)+ cations acting as extra charge balancing species occupy the channels of the anionic framework. The luminescent properties of polymer 1 at room temperature were investigated.
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A new Sr(II) coordination polymer (EMIm)4[Sr10(1,4-NDC)10Br4] 1 has been ionothermal synthesized using 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide as solvent and characterized by IR, elemental analysis, XRPD and X-ray crystallography, where 1,4-H2NDC is 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid. Polymer 1 displays a crystalline 3D framework, in which the anions of 1,4-H2NDC are embedded in three bridging coordination modes and Sr(II) centers show five coordination geometries. Each dodecanuclear metallocyclic ring segment formed by distorted edge-sharing and face-sharing Sr coordination polyhedra extends out to increase the dimensionality by strontium coordination polyhedra sharing to obtain a rare Sr-based 2D sheet. Organic bridging ligands connect adjacent layers giving rise to a 3D structure and (EMIm)+ cations acting as extra charge balancing species occupy the channels of the anionic framework. The luminescent properties of polymer 1 at room temperature were investigated.

elements.content: Much interest at present is focused on the rational design and construction of coordination polymers (CPs) owing to their intriguing aesthetic structures and special functional properties such as optics, redox activity and magnetism [1–4]. Many reaction factors, such as the types of organic ligands, metal–ligand ratio, solvent systems, counter ions, temperature and even the reaction time, are found to influence the kinetics and energetics of the growth of CPs. Among them, the introduction of green solvent systems is undoubtedly a design highlight in assembling CPs [5, 6]. In the past two decades, ionic liquids (ILs) have been widely used as “green solvents” replacing traditional organic solvents for organic synthesis and catalysis. Moreover, ionothermal synthesis as a promising method to prepare CPs has received remarkable attention in which ILs function as reaction media, structure templates or charge-compensating groups [7–9]. In comparison with aqueous solutions and/or typical organic solvents, ILs as organic salts composed completely of ions have many outstanding physicochemical properties, such as nonflammability, negligible vapor pressure, high ionic conductivity, excellent dissolving capacity, and thermostablility [10–12].
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Much interest at present is focused on the rational design and construction of coordination polymers (CPs) owing to their intriguing aesthetic structures and special functional properties such as optics, redox activity and magnetism [1-4]. Many reaction factors, such as the types of organic ligands, metal-ligand ratio, solvent systems, counter ions, temperature and even the reaction time, are found to influence the kinetics and energetics of the growth of CPs. Among them, the introduction of green solvent systems is undoubtedly a design highlight in assembling CPs [5, 6]. In the past two decades, ionic liquids (ILs) have been widely used as "green solvents" replacing traditional organic solvents for organic synthesis and catalysis. Moreover, ionothermal synthesis as a promising method to prepare CPs has received remarkable attention in which ILs function as reaction media, structure templates or charge-compensating groups [7-9]. In comparison with aqueous solutions and/or typical organic solvents, ILs as organic salts composed completely of ions have many outstanding physicochemical properties, such as nonflammability, negligible vapor pressure, high ionic conductivity, excellent dissolving capacity, and thermostablility [10-12].

elements.content: In many cases, ionothermal reactions often yield new materials, which cannot or not easily be made via conventional approaches. However, there are still limited known examples of coordination frameworks synthesized in ILs [7, 13–15], and most of these structures with metal cations being transitions and rare-earth but few in alkaline earth metals [16]. In the construction of CPs, alkaline earth-organic frameworks are still a subject of current interest because of the large atomic radii and broad span of coordination number of alkaline earth atoms making the topologies of polymers uncontrollable and diverting [17, 18]. To date, to the best of our knowledge, Sr-based CP has not been reported under ionothermal conditions. In the present study, as the luminescence behavior of product was desired, we opted to use 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid as functional component to synthesize an interesting 3D CP (EMIm)4[Sr10(1,4-NDC)10Br4] 1 using 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide as solvent. In 1 both the cations and anions of the ILs enter the resulting framework which displays strong fluorescent emission in the solid state at room temperature.

elements.content: All chemicals were of reagent grade quality obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. 1-Ethyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide ([EMIM]Br) IL was prepared according to the literature method [19]. Elemental analyses (C, H and N) were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analytical instrument. IR spectra were recorded in KBr pellets with a Nicolet 170 SXFT-IR spectrophotometer in the 4000–400 cm−1 region. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns were recorded on a D/max-γ A rotating anode X-ray diffractometer with Cu sealed tube (λ = 1.54178 Å), and the luminescent spectra were performed on a Hitachi F-7000 fluorescence spectrophotometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and Measurements

All chemicals were of reagent grade quality obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. 1-Ethyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide ([EMIM]Br) IL was prepared according to the literature method [19]. Elemental analyses (C, H and N) were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analytical instrument. IR spectra were recorded in KBr pellets with a Nicolet 170 SXFT-IR spectrophotometer in the 4000-400 cm-1 region. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns were recorded on a D/max-γ A rotating anode X-ray diffractometer with Cu sealed tube (λ = 1.54178 Å), and the luminescent spectra were performed on a Hitachi F-7000 fluorescence spectrophotometer.

elements.content: Polymer 1 was synthesized by ionothermal method. A mixture of 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (1,4-H2NDC) (0.241 g, 1.0 mmol), Sr(NO3)2·2H2O (0.211 g, 1.0 mmol), NaOH (0.086 g, 2.0 mmol) and [EMIM]Br (0.996 g) was sealed in a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel bomb and heated at 180 °C for 72 h. Then the autoclave was cooled to room temperature and the yellow crystals were isolated and washed with ethanol. Yield: ca. 62 % (based on 1,4-H2NDC). Calcd (%) for C144H104Br4N8O40Sr10: C, 45.73; H, 2.77; N, 2.96. Found: C, 45.62; H, 2.83; N, 3.02. IR (cm−1, KBr pellet): 3409(m), 1556(vs), 1512(w), 1461(m), 1418(s), 1369(vs), 1262(m), 1211(w), 1164(m), 1051(w), 881(w), 841(m), 789(m), 619(w), 574(w), 433(w), 376(w).

Synthesis of (EMIm)4[Sr10(1,4-NDC)10Br4] (1)

Polymer 1 was synthesized by ionothermal method. A mixture of 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid (1,4-H2NDC) (0.241 g, 1.0 mmol), Sr(NO3)2⋅2H2O (0.211 g, 1.0 mmol), NaOH (0.086 g, 2.0 mmol) and [EMIM]Br (0.996 g) was sealed in a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel bomb and heated at 180 °C for 72 h. Then the autoclave was cooled to room temperature and the yellow crystals were isolated and washed with ethanol. Yield: ca. 62 % (based on 1,4-H2NDC). Calcd (%) for C144H104Br4N8O40Sr10: C, 45.73; H, 2.77; N, 2.96. Found: C, 45.62; H, 2.83; N, 3.02. IR (cm-1, KBr pellet): 3409(m), 1556(vs), 1512(w), 1461(m), 1418(s), 1369(vs), 1262(m), 1211(w), 1164(m), 1051(w), 881(w), 841(m), 789(m), 619(w), 574(w), 433(w), 376(w).

elements.content: A suitable sample of size 0.20 mm × 0.15 mm × 0.13 mm was chosen for the crystallographic study and then mounted on a Bruker Smart APEX II CCD diffractometer with ω and φ scan mode in the range of 2.44° < θ < 20.92°. All diffraction measurements were performed at room temperature using graphite monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). A total of 36255 (12204 independent, Rint = 0.1084) reflections were measured. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined on F2 by using full-matrix least-squares methods with SHELXTL version 5.1 [20]. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by full-matrix least-squares techniques and all hydrogen atoms were geometrically fixed to allow riding on the parent atoms to which they are attached. Structure solution and refinement based on 7665 independent reflections with I > 2σ(I). Space group, lattice parameters and other relevant information are listed in Table 1 and selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table 2.

X-ray Crystallography

A suitable sample of size 0.20 mm × 0.15 mm × 0.13 mm was chosen for the crystallographic study and then mounted on a Bruker Smart APEX II CCD diffractometer with ω and φ scan mode in the range of 2.44° < θ < 20.92°. All diffraction measurements were performed at room temperature using graphite monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). A total of 36255 (12204 independent, Rint = 0.1084) reflections were measured. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined on F2 by using full-matrix least-squares methods with SHELXTL version 5.1 [20]. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by full-matrix least-squares techniques and all hydrogen atoms were geometrically fixed to allow riding on the parent atoms to which they are attached. Structure solution and refinement based on 7665 independent reflections with I > 2σ(I). Space group, lattice parameters and other relevant information are listed in Table 1 and selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table 2.

In the IR spectrum of polymer 1, the strong broaden absorption band at 1556 cm−1 shows the characteristic stretching frequency of ν(–CO2, asym), and the bands at 1418 and 1369 cm−1 are assigned as the ν(–CO2, sym) stretching frequency [21, 22]. This result indicates that the carboxyl groups of 1,4-H2NDC have joined in different coordination modes, which agrees well with the date of the other relevant compounds [16]. Their identities were finally confirmed by X-ray crystallography.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

IR Spectrum

In the IR spectrum of polymer 1, the strong broaden absorption band at 1556 cm-1 shows the characteristic stretching frequency of ν(-CO2, asym), and the bands at 1418 and 1369 cm-1 are assigned as the ν(-CO2, sym) stretching frequency [21, 22]. This result indicates that the carboxyl groups of 1,4-H2NDC have joined in different coordination modes, which agrees well with the date of the other relevant compounds [16]. Their identities were finally confirmed by X-ray crystallography.

elements.content: The structure analysis by X-ray single crystal diffraction revealed that the structure of 1 exhibits a crystalline 3D framework with exciting dodecanuclear metallocyclic ring (Sr12-ring) segments. The ORTEP diagram of 1 with the atomic numbering scheme and the coordination environment of metal ions is depicted in Fig. 1. The asymmetric unit consists of five Sr(II) atoms, five 1,4-NDC2− ligands, two Br− anions and two (EMIm)+ cations.
elements.clean_text:
Description of the Structure (EMIm)4[Sr10(1,4-NDC)10Br4] (1)

The structure analysis by X-ray single crystal diffraction revealed that the structure of 1 exhibits a crystalline 3D framework with exciting dodecanuclear metallocyclic ring (Sr12-ring) segments. The ORTEP diagram of 1 with the atomic numbering scheme and the coordination environment of metal ions is depicted in Fig. 1. The asymmetric unit consists of five Sr(II) atoms, five 1,4-NDC2- ligands, two Br- anions and two (EMIm)+ cations.

elements.content: Sr1 and Sr2 are located in seven-coordinated capped octahedral coordination geometry with O6Br set from five 1,4-NDC2− ligands and one Br− anion (Fig. 2). For Sr1, O6, O9, O10A, O15A, O20B and Br1 occupy the octahedral position while O5 occupies the capped position. Sr2 bonds to O11, O13, O18, O17, O8C, O14D and Br2, in which O17 occupies the capped position. The Sr1–O and Sr2–O distances are in the ranges of 2.439(12)–2.784(11) and 2.462(11)–2.766(10) Å, respectively. Different from the coordination modes of Sr1 and Sr2, the other three Sr centers (Sr3, Sr4 and Sr5) are eight-coordinate environment. Sr3 and Sr4 are coordinated by seven oxygen atoms and one three-link bromine atom. The seven oxygen donors around Sr3 metal center include two oxygen atoms (O1, O5) of two μ2–η2:η1 groups, four oxygen atoms (O9A, O10A, O15E, O16E) coming from two μ3–η2:η2 groups, another one oxygen atom O19F belonging to μ2–η1:η1 group. While Sr4 is connected with seven oxygen atoms of which O3G and O17 being in two μ2–η2:η1 carboxylate groups, O11, O12, O13D, O14D of two μ3–η2:η2 carboxylate groups and the remaining O7G coming from μ2–η1:η1 carboxylate group. The average strontium-oxygen distance is 2.67 Å for Sr3–O and 2.65 Å for Sr4–O, respectively. It is again of the type that the coordination environment of Sr5 is also eight-coordinated but with six oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O3G, O4G, O12, O16E) of four 1,4-NDC2− and two bromine atoms (Br1 and Br2D) around the metal center. The structure shows that the Sr5 adopts a distorted hexagonal bipyramidal configuration in which Br1 and Br2D occupy the vertex positions with the Br–Sr5–Br angel of 175.2° and the average Sr5–Br distance of 3.06 Å. The Sr5–O distances are in the range of 2.527(10)–2.983(16) Å.

elements.content: In the asymmetric unit of 1, the anions of 1,4-H2NDC present three interesting bridging ligands, μ6-(μ3–η2:η2)-(μ3–η2:η2) (1,4-NDC2−-1), μ4-(μ2–η2:η1)-(μ2–η2:η1) (1,4-NDC2−-2) and μ4-(μ2–η1:η1)-(μ2–η2:η1) (1,4-NDC2−-3), respectively (Fig. 3). An exciting dodecanuclear metallocyclic ring (Sr12-ring) segment is formed by distorted edge-sharing and face-sharing Sr coordination polyhedra, in which the trapped inside the void two 1,4-NDC2−-1 bridging ligands may have a great influence on structure (Fig. 4). As such, obvious face-to-face π–π interaction between two aromatic rings is found and characterized by the centroid–centroid separation of 3.70 Å, the shortest interplanar atom–atom separation of 3.57 Å, and the dihedral angel of 4.6°, respectively. Each Sr12-ring extends out to increase the dimensionality by strontium coordination polyhedra sharing to obtain a rare Sr-based 2D sheet. 1,4-NDC2−-2 and 1,4-NDC2−-3 connect adjacent layers giving rise to a 3D structure and (EMIm)+ cations acting as extra charge balancing species occupy the channels of the anionic framework (Fig. 5). It is interesting to note that there are obvious one type of face-to-face π–π interaction and multiform C–H···π interactions involving naphthalene rings and imidazole rings of ILs. The π–π interaction between two benzene rings of 1,4-NDC2−-2 and 1,4-NDC2−-3 is characterized by the centroid–centroid separation of 3.73 Å, the shortest interplanar atom–atom separation of 3.47 Å, and the dihedral angel of 12.0°, respectively. At the same time, there is one type of C–H···π interaction with the C···π separation of 3.62 Å and the C–H···π angle of 128.0°. Two C–H···π interactions between naphthalene rings and imidazole rings are characterized by the C···π separation of 3.34, 3.54 Å and the C–H···π angle of 136.8°, 106.2°, respectively. In addition, multiple hydrogen bonds, C–H···Br and C–H···O, are found in the network cooperatively stabilizing polymeric structure (Table 3). Apparently, extensive cooperativity throughout the crystals is important for such materials.

To ensure the phase purity of the samples for the luminescence determination, the XRPD pattern of 1 was performed. The dissimilarities in intensity may be due to the preferred orientation of the crystalline powder samples.

elements.content: Luminescence in CPs generally arises from conjugated organic ligands and/or metal ions or clusters [1]. Herein, we opted to use 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid as functional component to synthesize luminescence CP, due to they has exhibited behaviors in their rich structural chemistry and prominent luminescent properties [7, 16, 23–25]. On the other hand, although the photoluminescence was greatly enhanced by the coordination of alkaline earth metal ion, the luminescent properties of alkaline earth metal organic–inorganic hybrid materials in the solid states have not been well-studied up to now [16, 26]. Accordingly, the photoluminescent spectra of 1 in the solid state have been measured at the room temperature. Upon the excitation at 271 nm, polymer 1 shows a strong emission peak at 377 nm, as show in Fig. 7. Excitation of solid samples of 1 at 377 nm produces two emission peaks at 271 and 336 nm. The 271 nm excitation was chosen because it is suitable for polymer 1 to exist the strong emission peak. Compared to the luminescent spectrum of the free 1,4-H2NDC ligand at about 475 nm, the emission of 1 may be assigned to oxygen to Sr(II) charge transfer transitions, which is similar to that of {(EMIm)2[Zn7(μ4-O)2(1,4-NDC)6]}n [24]. Noticeably, aromatic components in the framework is expected to better attract each other through abundant π–π interactions and may play a key role in luminescent spectrum of 1.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Properties

Luminescence in CPs generally arises from conjugated organic ligands and/or metal ions or clusters [1]. Herein, we opted to use 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid as functional component to synthesize luminescence CP, due to they has exhibited behaviors in their rich structural chemistry and prominent luminescent properties [7, 16, 23-25]. On the other hand, although the photoluminescence was greatly enhanced by the coordination of alkaline earth metal ion, the luminescent properties of alkaline earth metal organic-inorganic hybrid materials in the solid states have not been well-studied up to now [16, 26]. Accordingly, the photoluminescent spectra of 1 in the solid state have been measured at the room temperature. Upon the excitation at 271 nm, polymer 1 shows a strong emission peak at 377 nm, as show in Fig. 7. Excitation of solid samples of 1 at 377 nm produces two emission peaks at 271 and 336 nm. The 271 nm excitation was chosen because it is suitable for polymer 1 to exist the strong emission peak. Compared to the luminescent spectrum of the free 1,4-H2NDC ligand at about 475 nm, the emission of 1 may be assigned to oxygen to Sr(II) charge transfer transitions, which is similar to that of {(EMIm)2[Zn7(μ4-O)2(1,4-NDC)6]}n [24]. Noticeably, aromatic components in the framework is expected to better attract each other through abundant π-π interactions and may play a key role in luminescent spectrum of 1.

elements.content: In summary, we presented a new CP (EMIm)4[Sr10(1,4-NDC)10Br4] (1) based on 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid by a ionothermal reaction in an imidazolium-based IL as solvent. The structure of polymer 1 has been established by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis and also characterized by IR, XRPD analysis and luminescent properties. Polymer 1 displays a crystalline 3D framework with dodecanuclear metallocyclic ring segments, in which both the cations and anions of the ILs enter the resulting framework. Multiform supramolecular interactions are found in the 3D structure and also play an important role in stabilizing the network. The fluorescence measurement of polymer 1 shows the strong emission peak in the solid state. Because ionothermal syntheses are efficient and environmentally benign, we believe that this strategy is very promising in the design and construction of functional CPs. Further such studies are currently underway.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we presented a new CP (EMIm)4[Sr10(1,4-NDC)10Br4] (1) based on 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid by a ionothermal reaction in an imidazolium-based IL as solvent. The structure of polymer 1 has been established by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis and also characterized by IR, XRPD analysis and luminescent properties. Polymer 1 displays a crystalline 3D framework with dodecanuclear metallocyclic ring segments, in which both the cations and anions of the ILs enter the resulting framework. Multiform supramolecular interactions are found in the 3D structure and also play an important role in stabilizing the network. The fluorescence measurement of polymer 1 shows the strong emission peak in the solid state. Because ionothermal syntheses are efficient and environmentally benign, we believe that this strategy is very promising in the design and construction of functional CPs. Further such studies are currently underway.
